In-situ synthesis of NiMo@SAPO-11 under mild conditions for the hydrodeoxygenation of triolein Dejiang Zheng Writing – original draft Validation Investigation Formal analysis Lu Li Writing – review & editing Methodology Formal analysis Conceptualization Shitao Yu Writing – review & editing Methodology Conceptualization ⁎ State Key Laboratory Base of Eco-chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, PR China State Key Laboratory Base of Eco-chemical Engineering College of Chemical Engineering Qingdao University of Science and Technology Qingdao PR China State Key Laboratory Base of Eco-chemical Engineering, College of Chemical Engineering, Qingdao University of Science and Technology, Qingdao, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Economical and sulphur-free Ni catalysts are attractive alternatives to hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of fats and oils for the production of diesel-range paraffins, but are prone to decarbonylation/decarboxylation (DCOx) reactions. Metal oxide decorated nickel catalysts exhibit remarkably high catalytic activity, which can modify the nickel catalyzed deoxygenation reaction pathway. Herein, a series of NiMo@SAPO-11 catalysts with different Ni/Mo mass ratio were prepared using an in-situ synthesis under mild conditions (100 °C, 12 h). The as-synthesized bimetallic NiMo nanocatalyst with a Ni/Mo mass ratio of 3:1 showed an excellent catalytic HDO activity with 100 % conversion of triolein and 86.5 % selectivity of octadecane. Combined with experimental results and density functional calculations, it was demonstrated that oxygen vacancies derived from MoOx considerably favored the adsorption and activation of substrates. An efficient selective HDO process for fats and oils has been achieved by direct deoxygenation of hydroxyl/carbonyl functional groups. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Synergistic effect NiMo alloy SAPO-11 Hydrodeoxygenation paths Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Demand for energy has risen sharply due to rapid population growth and economic development, and traditional fossil fuels can cause the emission of large quantities of poisonous and harmful substances owing to contain S and N elements [1,2]. Therefore, the conversion of sustainable alternative clean energy into biodiesel has attracted considerable attention [3,4]. However, the oxygen-containing components in biodiesel lead to low calorific value and poor stability. Therefore, it is crucial to remove the oxygen components from biodiesel [5]. Hydrodeoxygenation routes for fats and oils typically include hydrodecarbonylation (DCO), hydrodecarboxylation (DCO2) and hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [6]. Compared with the DCOX routes, the main advantage of the HDO pathway is that it typically leads to the cleavage of CO bonds while protecting the integrity of CC bonds, allowing it to more effectively convert biomass into fuels and chemicals and reducing the negative impact on the environment [7]. Conventional sulfide metal catalysts (e.g., MoS2 and CoMoS) exhibit excellent HDO performance of fats and oils [8,9], but require continuous sulfur replenishment to maintain activity during operation. However, it can contaminate the products owing to a large amount of sulphur species. Noble metal catalysts (e.g., Pt [10] and Pd [11]) demonstrate a high HDO catalytic activity and selectivity under mild conditions, but their scarcity, high cost as well as sintering of metals become obstacles to large-scale industrial application. Consequently, the development of an economical, environmentally friendly and sulfur-free catalysts for the hydrodeoxygenation of fats and oils has attracted considerable attention from researchers. Non-noble transition metal Ni is a worth-considering alternative for the hydrodeoxygenation of fats and oils due to its cost-effectiveness and high hydrodeoxygenation activity [12]. However, metallic Ni catalysts exhibit high activity for CC bond hydrogenolysis [13] and methanation reactions [14]. To inhibit these unexpected reactions, nickel metal was modified by introducing secondary metal (e.g., Co [15] and Fe [16]), or metal oxides (e.g., CeOX [17] and TiOX [18]) to improve hydrodeoxygenation performance with regard to the activity and selectivity. Specifically, the addition of the secondary metal alters the chemical environment of the monometallic Ni, including an electron transfer that modifies the electron density of Ni, thereby inhibiting side reactions. In addition, oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface play an important role in improving the hydrodeoxygenation activity as well as inhibiting the occurrence of side reactions. Generally, in addition to the participation of common active metal centers and supports, the heterogeneous catalytic process can facilitate the activation of substrates through the interaction between oxygen vacancies and oxygen-containing functional groups of substrates [19]. Oxophilic metals, such as Co, Ce and Fe, also have a strong affinity for oxygen. This makes the CO bond susceptible to adsorption, activation and breakage, while suppressing the breakage of CC bonds, thereby remarkably facilitating the hydrodeoxygenation process. After introducing Co in Ni-based catalysts, selectivity of C16 and C18 paraffins increase from 54.1 to 90.1 % in the hydrodeoxygenation of stearic acid. In addition, C15 and C17 paraffins (e.g., CC bond breakage) decreases from 36.7 to 6.5 % [20]. Catalyst's support also has an effect on the hydrodeoxygenation pathway and product selectivity of fats and oils. Diesel obtained from traditional HDO catalysts loaded with SiO2 or activated carbon is mainly composed of n-alkanes, which have poor flow properties and thus limit their use in high-altitude areas. Acidic supports are commonly used to increase iso-paraffins selectivity and may also affect the hydrodeoxygenation pathway [21]. Among these supports, SAPO-11 molecular sieves are commonly used supports for deoxygenation and isomerization catalysts due to its moderate acidity and shape selectivity. The general methods for synthesis of catalyst includes impregnation and in-situ synthesis, etc. Catalysts prepared by impregnation method generally have poor metal dispersion and large metal particle sizes, resulting in poor hydrodeoxygenation activity and selectivity [22]. Catalysts prepared by in-situ synthesis has been shown to be effective in alleviating the above problems and the synthesized catalysts are characterized by high activity and good stability [23]. In our current work, the NiMo@SAPO-11 catalyst was successfully produced by introducing nickel and molybdenum precursors as well as carbon materials into a microwave-assisted synthesis system. The synergistic catalysis of bimetallic NiMo alloy and abundant defective MoOX species significantly enhanced the HDO activity of triolein, achieving a C18 paraffins selectivity of 86.5 %, compared to 54.8 % for the monometallic Ni catalyst. It was found that abundant surface oxygen vacancies could significantly enhance the adsorption and activation of stearic acid and/or stearyl alcohol intermediates by breaking the COH and/or C=O bond, thereby considerably promoting the HDO progress. Moreover, DFT calculations of fatty acid adsorption on the MoOX-decorated NiMo alloy further confirm the aforementioned results. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Pseudo-boehmite (70 wt %) was purchased from Yantai Henghui Petrochemical Co., Ltd. Phosphoric acid (85 wt %), dipropylamine (99 wt %), nickel nitrate (98 wt %), ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate (99 wt %), n-heptane (99 wt %) and triolein (99 wt %) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Silicon sol (30 wt %) was purchased from Qingdao Haiyang Petrochemical Co. Ltd. Commercial SAPO-11 seed was purchased from Nankai Catalyst Co. Ltd. All chemicals were used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of NiMo@SAPO-11M under microwave radiation The NiMo@SAPO-11M was prepared via an in-situ microwave irradiation synthesized method from a gel composed of 1.0Al2O3: 1.0P2O5: 0.4SiO2: 1.1DPA: 90H2O: xNi(NO3)2·6H2O: y(NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (molar ratio), where x/y chosen as 0.133/0, 0.133/0.00035, 0.133/0.00105, 0.133/0.000175 and 0/0.00035. (i) pseudo-boehmite (2.19 g) and phosphoric acid (3.46 g) were mixed in deionized water (25 g) and vigorously agitating for 2 h. (ii) dipropylamine (1.70 g) was gradually added to the mixture followed by continuous agitating for 2 h. (iii) silicon sol (1.20 g) was gradually added and agitating for 2 h. (iv) Biochar (0.02 g), commercial SAPO-11 (0.2624 g) and a given amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and/or (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O were added to the mixture and agitating was stopped after 2 h and the mixture gel was left to age for 12 h at room temperature. (v) The homogenous gel (pH=5.0) was transferred into an autoclave for crystallization at 100 °C for 8–12 h under microwave radiation (1000 W). The final mixture was centrifugated and washed with deionized water several times, dried overnight at 100 °C, and calcined in a muffle oven at 650 °C for 5 h in the air to remove the organic template and biochar. The obtained catalysts were reduced at 500 °C for 4 h under H2 flow (50 mL/min) before use. The amount of Ni related to SAPO-11 was fixed at 3 wt %, and that amount of Mo was varied. The detailed amount of metal and catalysts labeling are shown in Table S1. 2.3 Synthesis of NiMo/SAPO-11W under hydrothermal condition Synthesis procedure was consistence with that of SAPO-11M. Microwave irradiation is replaced by oven heating and crystallization at 180 °C for 12 h. As a comparison, NiMo/SAPO-11 W catalyst with the same loading amount was produced by impregnation method. The bimetallic catalysts NiMo/SAPO-11W was named as NiMo/SAPO-11. The catalyst characterizations, product analysis method and DFT calculations can be found in the supporting information. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 In-situ synthesis of xNiyMo@SAPO-11 catalysts As shown in Fig. 1 (A), the AEL topology of SAPO-11 was observed in all catalysts, where precursor of nickel and/or molybdenum were added to the precursor gel to successfully prepare monometallic and bimetallic catalyst using impregnation (Fig. 1A(a)) and in-situ synthesis method (Fig. 1A(b-d)). As shown in Fig. 1A(b), as expected, weak metallic Ni diffraction peaks were observed on the 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst at 2θ=44.5°, 51.8° and 76.4°, corresponding to (111), (200) and (220) crystal planes of Ni phase (JCPDS # 04–0850) [24]. As shown in Fig. 1A(d), while strong diffraction peaks of MoO2 (JCPDS # 032–0671) and Mo4O11 crystalline phases (JCPDS # 05–0337) were also observed, respectively [25]. As shown in Fig. 1A(b), both Ni and Mo oxides diffraction peaks were detected on the 3Ni1Mo/SAPO-11 catalyst. Interestingly, neither MoO2 nor Ni diffraction peaks were detected on the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst, but only weak and wide peaks at 40.8°, 43.2° and 43.8°, corresponding to (041), (331) and (313) crystal planes of NiMo alloy (JCPDS # 48–1745) [26]. This indicates that the existence of Mo species favored the distribution of Ni species. It is then expected that for the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst most of the not observed Ni and Mo phase should be present as highly dispersed NiMoO4 species. As shown in Fig. 1(B), introduction of Mo species in the monometallic Ni catalysts led to the lattice expansion of Ni unit cell, and the (111) diffraction peak of Ni phase was transferred toward lower 2θ angles from 44.3° (3Ni@SAPO-11) to 43.8° (3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11), undoubtedly indicating that the formation of NiMo alloy. TEM characterizations were performed to demonstrate successful dispersion of Ni and/or Mo species on the SAPO-11 surface. As shown in Fig. S1(A), the NiMo bimetallic catalysts prepared by the impregnation technique exhibited larger particle size (13.48 nm) and were more prone to agglomeration. However, the mono/bimetallic catalysts produced by the in-situ synthesis technique had a smaller particle size (6.68 nm) and better dispersion (Fig. S1(B-D)). The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of three catalysts were shown in Fig. S2(A). Three catalysts showed typical type I and IV isotherms with hysteresis loops, indicating that they possess mesoporous structure. BET surface areas of three catalysts were comparable in Table S2. The BET surface areas and mesoporous volume of 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalysts gradually decreased as the metal content increased. As shown in Fig. S2(B), mesopore sizes of three catalysts were centered at ∼15 and ∼35 nm. 3.2 xNiyMo@SAPO-11 catalytic HDO reaction of triolein For the purpose of investigating the hydrodeoxygenation performance of the in-situ synthesized catalysts, we selected triolein as a waste cooking oil compound to evaluate the HDO performance of each catalyst. Furthermore, we compared the catalytic activity of NiMo/SAPO-11 catalysts prepared by impregnation for catalytic HDO of triolein in order to highlight the high activity of the in-situ synthesized catalysts (Table 1 ). An 87.0 % triolein conversion was achieved using the 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst in the HDO of triolein, with a paraffin selectivity of 90.0 % (35.2 % heptadecane and 54.8 % octadecane). This is attributed to Ni promoting the DCOx of fatty acids, resulting in the formation of heptadecane. In contrast, the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst exhibited enhanced catalytic activity, with the triolein conversion increased to 99.9 % and an increase in paraffin selectivity from 90.0 % to 96.2 % (6.3 % heptadecane and 86.5 % octadecane). The NiMo/SAPO-11 catalyst achieves a high conversion of 98.0 %, but exhibits a low selectivity of octadecane (66.8 %). This is attributed to the existence of exposed Ni sites and NiMo alloy on the surface of the 3Ni1Mo/SAPO-11 catalyst. The 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst exhibits superior catalytic efficiency and selectivity as compared to those reported in previous literature, both in terms of fats and oils conversion and octadecane selectivity. The molecular characteristics of Ni and Mo species found on the reduced catalysts were determined by Raman spectra. As shown in Fig. 2 A(a), no obvious bands corresponding to Ni species were found on the 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst, indicating a high dispersion of Ni species on the support. The weak peaks appearing at 280, 332, 660, 819 and 992 cm−1 were attributed to the MoO3 phase on the 1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst, which is in agreement with previous studies [30–32]. The weak and broad peaks at 910, 945 and 964 cm−1 were assigned to the NiMoO4 phase in the bimetallic 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst, further confirming that Ni and Mo species participated in the formation of NiMoO4 phase (NiMo alloy). The Raman band at 376 cm−1 was attributed to symmetric bending modes of isolated MoO4 units. Interestingly, Raman spectra corresponding to MoO3 crystals were not observed on the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst, demonstrating that the distribution of Mo species on the SAPO-11 support is quite high, which confirms the aforementioned XRD speculations. The active centers on the surface of the monometallic 3Ni@SAPO-11 and 1Mo@SAPO-11 catalysts are metal Ni and MoOX sites, respectively. The active center on the surface of the bimetallic 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst is NiMoO4 (NiMo alloy) and MoOX. The superior catalytic performance of the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst compared to monometallic catalysts (3Ni@SAPO-11 and 1Mo@SAPO-11) arises from the synergistic effect between the NiMo alloy and MoOX. The redox behavior of metal oxides and the metal-support interactions were investigated using the H2-TPR method. As shown in Fig. 2B(a), three reduction peaks were observed at 434, 543 and 610 °C for the 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst, corresponding to the reduction peak of bulk NiO species with poor interactions with the SAPO-11, the reduction peak of highly dispersed NiO species with intimate interactions with the SAPO-11 and the reduction peak of nickel aluminate species, respectively. In contrast, three reduction peaks 630, 744 and 850 °C were also observed for the 1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst (Fig. 2B(c)), corresponding to the reduction of octahedral coordination Mo species (Mo6+→Mo5+/Mo4+), further reduction of Mo4+ to low valence state of Mo (Mo3+/Mo2+) and the reduction of Mo2+ to Mo0, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2B(b), only two H2 consumption peaks were observed for the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst. The first peak, corresponding to the reduction of NiO to Ni0, appeared at a higher temperature (434→485 °C), whereas the second peak, shifted to a higher temperature with an enhanced area, arose from NiMoO4 reduction to NiMo alloy. This is definitive evidence of a strong interaction between Ni and Mo. Interestingly, the lower H2 consumption peak of 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst compared to that of 1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst from 580 to 650 °C demonstrated that the predominant form of Mo species is NiMoO4 rather than MoO3 phase, as already concluded from the XRD and Raman results. Yang et al. [33] reported similar H2-TPR curves for NiMo/SiO2 catalyst, which proved the reduction of NiMoO4 phase from 450 to 550 °C rather than MoO3 phase. The above results are consistent with the Raman findings. XPS was carried out to explore any probable electronic interactions and chemical states between Ni and Mo. As shown in Fig. 3 (A), three peaks of Ni 2p can be deconvoluted by a Gaussian peak fitting method. For the monometallic 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst, the two peaks at 852.9 and 856.9 eV correspond to Ni0 and Ni2+, respectively, with additional shake-up satellite peaks at 862.3 eV [34]. The peak of Ni0 shifts to 853.3 eV in bimetallic catalyst with the incorporation of Mo atoms, indicating a charge shift from the metallic Ni to MoOX surface, which is consistent with the previously reported bimetallic catalyst [33]. In addition, a higher Ni0 content was obtained in the XPS spectrum of Ni 2p for the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst (18.2 %) compared to the 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst (9.3 %), indicating that Mo species can alter NiO interactions with SAPO-11 and facilitate the reduction of NiO by facilitating the distribution of Ni species. As listed in Table S3, a large fraction of Ni was easily oxidized in the monometallic 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst, while the degree of oxidation was much lower in the bimetallic 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst. This trend supports the coverage of Ni by MoOX species and the chemical modification of Ni, resulting it being less oxyphilic. As shown in Fig. 3(B), the deconvoluted peaks of Mo 3d spectra are located at ∼229.4, ∼230.8 and ∼232.3 eV, assigned to Mo4+, Mo5+ and Mo6+, respectively [35]. As listed in Table S3, compared with the 1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst (59.5 %), the XPS spectra of the 3NiMo@SAPO-11 catalyst showed higher levels of Mo4+and Mo5+ (67.6 %), indicating that Ni facilitates the reduction of MoO3 species, which is consistent with the H2-TPR results of the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst. Meanwhile, it is observed that the binding energy of Mo4+ 3d shifts to lower binding energies, revealing the existence of increased electron transfer from Ni-Mo alloy (NiMoO4) to MoOX species. As shown in Fig. 3(C), the deconvoluted peaks of the O 1s fine spectrum, three fitted peaks at ∼531.6, ∼532.7 and ∼533.8 eV, attributed to lattice oxygen (OⅠ), oxygen vacancies (OⅡ), and adsorbed CO2 or carbonate species (OⅢ), respectively [36,37]. Compared to the monometallic 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst, more OⅡ species are formed in the bimetallic catalyst, confirming the formation of defective MoOX species (Mo5+-OⅡ-Mo5+) in the bimetallic catalyst. According to the XPS results (Table S3 and S4), the OⅡ/(OⅠ+OⅡ) ratio (0.59) in the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst is the highest, consistent with the highest Mo5+ content (28.3 %). The oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface were further verified by electron spin resonance spectroscopy (EPR). All catalysts show a pair of symmetrical peaks at g ≈ 2.003, a typical signal for oxygen vacancies, as shown in Fig. 3(D). EPR intensity was also used to determine the relative content of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, which decreased in the order: 3NiMo@SAPO-11 > 1Mo@SAPO-11 > 3Ni@SAPO-11. The above results are consistent with the XPS findings. In order to observe the influence of metal particle dispersion on catalyst surface performance, TEM studies were carried out to investigate how adding Mo species affects Ni particles size and potentially promotes the formation of NiMo alloys. As shown in Fig. 4 , massive nanoparticles were observed on both mono- and bimetallic catalysts, indicating that Ni and/or Mo species were successfully dispersed on the surface of SAPO-11. The 3Ni@SAPO-11 and 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalysts had similar average particle sizes of 5.34 nm and 6.68 nm, respectively, while the 1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst had a larger average particle size of 9.33 nm. The HRTEM image of 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst displays a lattice spacing of 0.203 nm, corresponding to the Ni (111) plane (Fig. 4e). In contrast, the lattice spacing of MoO2 observed in the 1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst is 0.340 nm, corresponding to the (1̄11) plane (Fig. 4 g). For the bimetallic 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst, a large lattice spacing of 0.206 nm is found (Fig. 4f), corresponding to the NiMo alloy phase, which demonstrates that the doping of Mo atoms into the Ni lattice. In addition, a clear lattice spacing of 0.235 nm is assignable to MoOX phase in the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 and 1Mo@SAPO-11 catalysts. Furthermore, the uniform distributions of Ni, Mo and O elements are found on the basis of the EDS Mapping of the HADDF-STEM image (Fig. 4j, 4k and 4l), while the STEM-EDX line scan (Fig. 4d and 4h) show the distributions of Ni, Mo and O elements, clearly indicating that Ni and Mo elements exhibit a relatively uniform distribution, indicating a strong intimate interaction between Ni and Mo species, which is also confirmed by XRD, Raman and H2-TPR results. NH3-TPD was performed to investigate the effect of Ni and/or Mo species on the surface strength and acid distribution of catalysts. The curves, fitted curves and acidic sites densities are shown in Fig. 5 (A), Fig. S3 and Table S5. Three NH3 desorption peaks centered at ∼153, 300, and 462 °C were observed for all catalysts, equivalent to weak acid, medium acid, and strong acid, respectively [38]. For the 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst, a strong acid peak is observed at ∼500 °C, correlating with the strong interaction between NH3 and bridge-OH and/or Si-OH and/or groups, which always function as Brønsted acidic sites. Compared to the 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst, the total acidity of the catalyst gradually decreases with the addition of Mo species (Table S5), which is attributed to the coverage of acidic sites on the SAPO-11 surface by the metal. However, the strong acid content of the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst increases, which is attributed to the introduction of Mo species (Mo4+ and Mo6+) compared to the 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst [39]. The catalyst has a high catalytic efficiency due to the increase in strong acid sites. Pyridine FTIR spectroscopy was further employed to characterize the acid types of investigated samples (Fig. 5B and 5C), with the distribution of acid types across various evacuation temperatures (150 and 300 °C) presented in Table S6. In the range of 1700–1400 cm−1, the characteristic bands at approximately 1449, 1607 and 1540 cm−1 correspond to pyridine adsorbed on Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites, while the band at ∼1491 cm−1 is associated with the adsorption of pyridine at Lewis and Brønsted acidic sites [40]. Based on Table S6, the Lewis acid content in the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst shows a notable increase (increased from 93.7 to 181.9 μmol/g) compared to the 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst, correlating with an augmented presence of Mo species. A higher Lewis acid content facilitates the cleavage of CO bonds in triolein, thereby promoting its hydrodeoxygenation pathway and significantly increasing the yield of octadecane. In contrast, the 3N@SAPO-11 catalyst exhibits a higher Brønsted acid content compared to the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst. This enhanced Brønsted acidity facilitates carbocation rearrangement reaction, leading to a higher iso-paraffins during the catalytic reaction. The higher the content of iso-paraffins in biodiesel, the lower the cloud point and condensation point, which can improve the flowability of biodiesel when used at low-temperature environments. 3.3 The effect of Ni/Mo mass ratio on catalytic HDO of triolein over xNiyMo@SAPO-11 catalysts Table 2 shows the effect of Ni/Mo mass ratio on HDO performance of catalysts. Whereas the triolein conversion decreased from 100 % to 90.9 % as the Ni/Mo mass ratio decreased from 3/1 to 3/5, accompanied by a decrease of alkanes and iso-paraffins selectivity from 92.8 % to 47.3 % and 11.5 % to 3.7 %, respectively, and the selectivity of fatty alcohols increased from 3.8 % to 53.7 %. The XRD results indicate that large Mo aggregates are formed on the catalyst surface with the increasing Mo content, which are responsible for the MoO2 diffraction peaks in 3Ni3Mo@SAPO-11 and 3Ni5Mo@SAPO-11 catalysts (Fig. 6 A). A large amount of MoO2 covers the NiMo alloy sites, leading to a decrease in catalytic efficiency for triolein and intermediates, resulting in the production of more intermediates. The Raman results indicate the presence of a large amount of unreduced MoO3 species on the catalyst surface, and as the Mo content increases, the peak corresponding to NiMoO4 species gradually decreases, indicating that a large amount of MoO3 species covers the surface of NiMoO4, leading to a decrease in its catalytic activity (Fig. 6C). As shown in Fig. 6(D), H2-TPR results demonstrate that the bimetallic xNiyMo catalysts exhibited distinct reduction behaviors compared to the monometallic catalysts. With the increase of Mo content, the MoO3 species on the catalyst surface easily agglomerated into large particles and covered the NiMoO4 species, leading to a shift in the reduction temperature of the metal oxides to the higher temperature regions, reducing the NiMoO4 active sites on the catalyst surface and lowering the catalytic performance. XPS results indicate that the Ni0 content gradually decreases (3Ni3Mo@SAPO-11: 8.9 %, 3Ni5Mo@SAPO-11: 6.5 %) in the bimetallic catalyst (Table S7) as the Mo content increases, because excessive Mo will cover the metal Ni species, making the reduction of NiO species more difficult. This is consistent with the results of H2-TPR, XRD and Raman. In addition, lower valence Mo2+ species was observed on the 3Ni3Mo@SAPO-11 and 3Ni5Mo@SAPO-11 catalysts (Fig. 7 B), which is attributed to the fact that as the Mo/Ni mass ratio increases, excess Mo species cannot form NiMoO4 species with Ni species, but instead cover the surface of SAPO-11 in the form of isolated MoO3, resulting in weaker interaction with SAPO-11 and easier reduction to lower valence Mo species (e.g., Mo2+). This was also confirmed by XRD, Raman and H2-TPR results. 3.4 Investigation on the single factor process of catalytic triolein Fig. 8 (A-C) shows the effect of reaction temperature, reaction time and H2 pressure on the HDO performance of 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst. As the reaction temperature, reaction time and H2 pressure increased, the conversion and alkane selectivity of triolein gradually increased, reaching a maximum at 290 °C. As the reaction temperature, reaction time and H2 pressure increased were further increased, the alkane selectivity decreased owing to the CC bond cleavage. Therefore, 290 °C, 6 h and 4 MPa were selected as the optimal reaction conditions. Fig. 8(D) shows the effect of the mass ratio of catalyst/substrate on the HDO performance of 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst. Both the conversion and the paraffin selectivity of triolein gradually increased with the mass ratio of catalyst/substrate with 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11, eventually reaching the maximum value at the ratio of 0.4 and 0.5, respectively. Less catalyst means fewer acidic sites and active metals, while an excessive amount of catalyst can be unnecessarily wasteful. Therefore, the catalyst/substrate ratio should be the optimal 0.4 to fully convert triolein into alkane. 3.5 Hydrodeoxygenation reaction mechanism exploration Typically, bimetallic catalysts had higher catalytic performance due to their unique synergistic effects as compared with the monometallic catalysts. As shown in Table 3 , bimetallic 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 (3.72 h−1) showed higher TOF values than that of monometallic 3Ni@SAPO-11 (1.37 h−1) and 1Mo@SAPO-11 (0.81 h−1) under the identical reaction conditions, indicating that the introduction of Mo species is crucial to enhance the catalytic activity. Based on the above results, the introduced Ni and Mo species interacted to form NiMo alloy predominantly dispersed on the catalyst surface, suggesting their likely contribution to the high catalytic activity. To acquire further information about the interaction of fats and oils with the 3Ni@SAPO-11 and 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalysts, the adsorption-desorption behavior of fats and oils on the catalyst surface was investigated using in-situ FT-IR spectra (Fig. 9 ). As shown in Fig. S4, TG analysis was performed on the triolein, resulting in a mass loss of 4.20 wt % (temperature increased from 20 to 300 °C), while the mass loss of triolein that would theoretically convert to oleic acid during thermal cracking was 4.30 wt %. To further investigate the thermal cracking products of triolein, samples after thermogravimetric testing were subjected to acid-base titration, and the acid value was 150 mgKOH/g. The acid value of the same mass of oleic acid (standard sample) was 155 mgKOH/g. Therefore, it was concluded that triolein was gradually converted into oleic acid during thermal cracking. Here, propionic acid with a lower boiling point was used to investigate the interaction between catalysts and fats and oils due to its analogous functional groups with fats and oils and the high boiling point of triolein, which makes it difficult to evaporate. For the purpose of determining the function of oxygen vacancies in the catalytic HDO process, the desorption of capacity propionic acid on catalysts was studied using in situ FT-IR spectra (Fig. 9(A, B)). The bands near 1468 and 1410 cm−1 correspond to the stretching vibrations of CH and OH bonds in propionic acid, respectively. The band near 1720 cm−1 is attributed to the adsorption of carbonyl groups in propionic acid on oxygen vacancies. The bands near 1693 and 1420 cm−1 are attributed to the adsorption of carbonyl groups in propionic acid on Ni0 species. The signal intensity of 3Ni@SAPO-11 and 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalysts are similar at 1720 cm−1 at lower desorption temperatures (< 200 °C). However, when the desorption temperature exceeds 300 °C, the signal intensity of the 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst significantly decreases, while the signal intensity on 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst is well maintained. Given that the band formed by the 1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst (Fig. S5) at 1713 cm−1 exhibits a similar trend to that of the 3Ni@SAPO-11 catalyst, it confirms the intimate interaction between the adsorbed propionic acid and oxygen vacancies. This is consistent with the XPS and EPR results. As shown in Fig. 10 , DFT calculations were performed on the Ni (111), NiMoOx (313), and Mo (1̄11) to define the active sites and adsorption modes. In the monometallic Ni system (Fig. 10A), oxygen in the hydroxyl group of propionic acid molecules adsorbs on top site of Ni, while the alkyl chain exhibits weak and tilted physical adsorption on Ni site. For the bimetallic NiMoOx system (Fig. 10B), the oxygen in the hydroxyl group of propionic acid molecules is bridge-adsorbed on the Ni site, and the carbon atom in the carbonyl group is adsorbed on the Mo site. In addition, the oxygen atom in the hydroxyl group is adsorbed on to the oxygen vacancies in the MoOx cluster. In the case of the monometallic Mo system (Fig. 10C), both the oxygen in the hydroxyl group and the carbon atom in the carbonyl group of propionic acid molecules are adsorbed on the Mo site. Meanwhile, the COH bond length carboxyl group decreases in the following order: NiMoOx (1.424 Å) > Ni (1.404 Å) > Mo (1.390 Å), along with the decreasing ΔEads value in the following order: NiMoOx (−0.72 eV) > Ni (−0.42 eV) > Mo (−0.38 eV). Therefore, it is reasonably concluded that the enlarged CO bond length may promote to the adsorption activation and dissociation ability of hydroxyl groups. Compared with the adsorption effect of propionic acid on Ni and Mo catalyst surface, the oxygen vacancies can accept lone pair electrons from oxygen atoms in hydroxyl groups and form a stable bonding state, which can considerably elongate and weaken the CO bonds. In-situ FTIR characterization was conducted to further demonstrate the adsorption and activation of COH bonds on different catalyst surfaces (Fig. S6). Broad and strong characteristic signals were observed around 1410 cm−1 for all three catalysts, attributed to the -OH vibration in the propionic acid molecule. Compared with monometallic Ni or Mo catalysts, a slight blue shift of the -OH band was observed at 1412 cm−1 on the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst, indicating strong adsorption of -OH by oxygen vacancies and NiMo alloy sites. Moreover, with the increase of desorption temperature, it can still be observed at higher desorption temperatures (> 300 °C). In conclusion, based on the DFT calculation and catalyst characterization results, it can be reasonably deduced that the high catalytic HDO performance of the NiMo bimetallic catalyst is mostly contributed by the NiMo alloy effect and the strong interaction of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface with the oxygen-containing functional groups of the substrates. In light of the aforementioned characterization and analysis of the catalytic reaction results, as well as the DFT calculations of the optimized adsorption configurations of fats and oils on the surface of mono- and bimetallic catalysts, it can be confirmed that Ni and MoOx species exhibit a synergistic effect. A probable mechanism for the HDO of triolein in the MoOX-decorated bimetallic NiMo catalyst system is tentatively proposed (Fig. 11 ). During the process of HDO of triolein, which first undergoes a hydrogenolysis process and is gradually converted to oleic acid and propane, oleic acid is further hydrogenated to stearic acid. Secondly, the oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface coordinate with the oxygen atoms in the hydroxyl groups of the stearic acid, resulting in lengthening and weakening of the CO bond and the generation of active hydrogen species on NiMo alloy sites. Subsequently, the carbonyl bonds in stearaldehyde adsorbed on the active site undergo two distinct pathways: (i) Direct decarbonylation on exposed Ni sites produces CO and heptadecane. (ii) Hydrogenation mediated by NiMo alloy near oxygen vavancies produces stearyl alcohol. Stearyl alcohol undergoes dehydration reaction at the Brønsted acid sites of SAPO-11, forming octadecene and water. The octadecene is further hydrogenated to generate octadecane. Finally, the heptadecane and octadecane are desorbed from the catalyst surface. In particular, the NiMo bimetallic catalyst, which contains a greater number of oxygen vacancies on its surface, exhibits synergistic catalytic activity when combined with the NiMo alloy and oxygen vacancies. The NiMo alloy plays a role in dissociating hydrogen, while the oxygen vacancies activate carbonyl group of stearaldehyde, facilitating the generation of octadecane along the HDO pathway. To ascertain whether heptadecane was produced through the DCO or DCO2 pathway, stearic acid was subjected to reaction under a nitrogen atmosphere. The reaction results demonstrated that no heptadecane was detected in the liquid product, indicating that its formation occurred via the DCO pathway since no aldehyde intermediates were generated under a nitrogen atmosphere. Catalyst recyclability is critical to the potential use of a catalytic process. As shown in Fig. 12 (A, B), after five recycling tests, the triolein conversion and octadecane selectivity of the 3Ni1Mo/SAPO-11 catalyst decreased by 23.0 % (from 100.0 % to 77.0 %) and 21.5 % (from 66.8 % to 45.3 %), respectively. Nevertheless, the triolein conversion and octadecane selectivity of the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst only decreased by 8.7 % (from 100.0 % to 91.3 %) and 16.3 % (from 86.5 % to 70.2 %). As shown in Fig. 12(C-F), the average particle size of the catalysts prepared by impregnation and in-situ synthesis techniques increased from 13.48 nm to 16.38 nm and from 6.68 nm to 7.75 nm, respectively, after 5 cycles. The difference in the catalytic performance of the two catalysts for triolein was attributed to the difference in the surface metal particle size. The larger metal particle size of the 3Ni1Mo/SAPO-11 catalyst led to a more significant decrease in catalytic performance during recycling, whereas the particle size of the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst did not change greatly after recycling, resulting in a better catalytic performance. Moreover, the XPS characterization was used to define the cause of the deactivation of the 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst, as shown in Fig. S7. The XPS results indicated that, compared to the fresh 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst, the used catalyst was partially oxidized after five cycle tests, showing a decrease in Ni0 content and an increase in Mo6+ content. These results demonstrate that the oxidation of surface metals primarily caused the catalyst's deactivation during the five cycles. 4 Conclusions In summary, MoOX-decorated bimetallic NiMo alloy nanocatalyst can be successfully synthesized in-situ under mild conditions. The as-synthesized 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst exhibits significantly high activity in the HDO of triolein. On the basic of in-situ FTIR and DFT calculations, it was demonstrated that surface oxygen vacancies on MoOX species could considerably enhance the adsorption and activation of substrates (triolein and intermediates). Thus, the oxygen-containing hydroxyl group of stearic acid could be directly deoxygenated to form stearaldehyde, which is further hydrogenated to convert to stearyl alcohol. The construction of the current high-efficiency catalytic system for the HDO of triolein over a surface oxygen vacancy-modified bimetallic 3Ni1Mo@SAPO-11 catalyst provides reasonable guidelines for the development of other high-efficiency catalysts for the catalytic upgrading of others fats and oils. coredata.dc:description: Economical and sulphur-free Ni catalysts are attractive alternatives to hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of fats and oils for the production of diesel-range paraffins, but are prone to decarbonylation/decarboxylation (DCOx) reactions. Metal oxide decorated nickel catalysts exhibit remarkably high catalytic activity, which can modify the nickel catalyzed deoxygenation reaction pathway. Herein, a series of NiMo@SAPO-11 catalysts with different Ni/Mo mass ratio were prepared using an in-situ synthesis under mild conditions (100 °C, 12 h). The as-synthesized bimetallic NiMo nanocatalyst with a Ni/Mo mass ratio of 3:1 showed an excellent catalytic HDO activity with 100 % conversion of triolein and 86.5 % selectivity of octadecane. Combined with experimental results and density functional calculations, it was demonstrated that oxygen vacancies derived from MoOx considerably favored the adsorption and activation of substrates. An efficient selective HDO process for fats and oils has been achieved by direct deoxygenation of hydroxyl/carbonyl functional groups.
coredata.dc:title: In-situ synthesis of NiMo@SAPO-11 under mild conditions for the hydrodeoxygenation of triolein
